Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Approximation and Hardness from Strong Relaxations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Discrete optimization lies at the core of computer science and its applications. Except for a few special cases, exact optimization is computationally intractable. Approximation algorithms seek to resolve this issue by providing computational efficiency and at the same time provable guarantees on the quality of solutions. The current project addresses fundamental open questions about approximation algorithms. The project will use strong relaxations, especially the sum-of-squares method, as a lens to shed light on these questions.

The Unique Games Conjecture has fueled many recent advances in our understanding of approximation algorithms. A proof of this conjecture would show that for a large classes of problems the approximation guarantees of a concrete algorithm are best possible. On the other hand, a refutation of the conjecture would likely lead to major improvements of approximation algorithms for a wide range of problems. Recent works of the PI and coauthors identified a candidate algorithm to refute the Unique Games Conjecture. This algorithm is able to solve previously proposed constructions of hard instances for problems that the conjecture predicts to be NP-hard. An integral part of the research project is to resolve whether this algorithm indeed refutes the conjecture.

The candidate algorithm comes from a meta-algorithm, called sum-of-squares method. The current project will also study the approximation guarantees of this method beyond the Unique Games Conjecture, and investigate the thesis that for a large class of problems, the sum-of-squares method is an optimal meta-algorithm in terms of approximation guarantee and time complexity.

A broad range of academic disciplines apply optimization techniques and computational efficiency is an important factor in these applications. In practice, meta-algorithms are often a popular choice, e.g., belief propagation, MCMC methods and SAT solvers, but lack provable approximation guarantees. The sum-of-squares method has the potential to achieve the same versatility as other meta-algorithms but with the additional benefit of provable guarantees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to gain insights into the power and limitations of efficient algorithms by investigating a specific family of algorithms, collectively called the sum-of-squares method. These algorithms work by rephrasing combinatorial or statistical problems as equivalent optimization problems over real-valued multivariate polynomials, then modifying those problems by limiting the degrees of the polynomials involved, and finally solving them using a powerful optimization method called semidefinite programming which is known to be solvable by efficient algorithms. One of the main outcomes of this project was the discovery that, for a broad range of statistical inference problems, the sum-of-squares method either matches or improves upon the best previously known methods, in terms of the sample complexity (i.e., the amount of data) required to efficiently solve the statistical inference problem. For example, the project discovered novel applications of the sum-of-squares method to improve the state of the art for outlier-robust estimation of Gaussian mixture models (one of the most fundamental high-dimensional statistical estimation problems) and stochastic block models (a cornerstone of social network modeling and community detection research).

One of the advantages of using the sum-of-squares method as a lens for studying the power and limitations of efficient algorithms is that the sum-of-squares paradigm is limited enough that we can, in many cases, prove unconditionally that this family of algorithms lacks the power to solve certain problems in polynomial time. Thus, for example, many of the aforementioned sample complexity bounds for statistical inference were shown to be optimal, in the sense that efficient sum-of-squares algorithms were shown to be incapable of solving the same statistical inference problem when provided with asymptotically fewer samples. As another example, the research in this project was able to show that the sum-of-squares method achieves near-optimal performance among wide families of all linear programming and semidefinite programming relaxations of various combinatorial optimization problems, thereby enabling the ruling out of any computationally efficient semidefinite programming relaxations by analysis of only the sum-of-squares relaxation.

Taken together, these results establish the sum-of-squares method as a powerful tool both for designing new algorithms and for identifying potential obstacles to the solution of combinatorial and statistical problems by efficient algorithms.
